See the Paper "The toppling of a uniform rectangular block" American Journal of Physics Nov 2021. A single domino will eventually slide no matter what the surface, but at ever larger angles as the friction increases. For large friction and close spacing the impact with the next domino will occur before slipping, but at larger spacing and low friction slipping will occur before impact with the next domino. This will affect the time interval and the impulse on the following domino and hence the speed of the toppling wave. It would be nice to have data on the felt and the wood floor at different domino spacing but I realize that the work for one spacing was already more than enough. It would also be interesting to have dominos with a small protrusion at the center of the top edge so it always hits the next domino on its center line. Great work, loved it and your other videos.

I feel wood where they slip is faster because; 1) the fall is shorter because of the slip; 2) the erratic hit of the domino is easier to clear itself because of the less friction on the floor surface. 3) on the non slipping surface, the bottom of the first domino is closer to the bottom of the second domino because the first didn't slip back. Now as the second falls there is more weight on the second because the first has more surface contact on the second which is more friction.  With the slipping surface the corner of the first domino is in longer contact with the second domino instead of the entire surface area meaning less friction because the contact area is smaller. Also, as the first falls and slips instead of it's main contact being at the top and just causing the second to tip over the first slides down the second and uses that force to push the second domino over instead of just tipping it over. Just a thought.

The problem about sliding average for noise is that if you have one point that is far of it will lead to a broad maximum or minimum in the averaged data. I would always try to avoid averaging data this way, because this way the data looks way more systematic than it is, and one or two "failed" points can already lead to something that looks systematic in the averaged data. You can see it at 7:05: I bet if you keep the 12th & 13th last point from hardwood out of the average, you will not see any increase at the end anymore at all. The speed increases there due to probably some different distance between the 14th & 13th last dominos, and therefore it LOOKS in the averaged data like the speed in the whole area of 20 dominos around these two increases systematically, while its only these two.
The noise can get you more information as well: In the felt data at 7:05 one can clearly see a systematic decaying noise in the beginning that looks quite similar to the curvature of an damped harmonic oscillator without sign change. Actually really good looking data as these narrow maxima could also easyly be halved and broadened if they would be shifted just like half a point distance. So I think the twist of the dominos can be described as an harmonic oszillator, and the felt damps the twist. I think this twist comes in the beginning from imperfect hit of the very first domino, and as the felt holds the dominos more, the time constant of the oszillator is higher there, it needs longer to oscillate out into an undamped oszillation (which makes also sense as one could understand gravity in this case as a periodic excitation). In the hardwood case this whole damping in the beginning cannot be seen as the time constant ist to small, so the whole damping happens in much less time / dominos, as hardwood doesn't hold the dominos so much. And then the whole damping is ofc also covered by other effects in the beginning like the acceleration of the whole system.

Hey Destin.
I just watched this domino/physics video. I am a practical application engineer/carpenter/mechanic/designer/teacher/musician. As I watched your observations my thoughts wandered back to when I was a child in the 60s. Space and physics have always amazed me. Here are a couple of considerations.
1. Gravity
2. Earth's rotation
3. Gyroscopic reverberation
4. Concusive reaction
5. Rebound
6. Sonic frequency
Ok, so there are more than a couple. Ha ha ha...
A part of the baseline to consider must be dominoes of different materials to observe the variables in reactions. For example: You used clear acrylic dominoes. What about the standard ebony (black wooden) type or dense white plastic, marble, aluminum, stainless steel, and so many others that dominoes have been made of.
My observations caused me to think about so many of the variables and even counter-variables such as momentum responding to the impact which in turn reacts to the vibrations caused by the impact becoming a completely different and opposing force causing the tiles to walk backwards while still falling forward. The noise on hardwood clearly allows far more reactions to be seen as compared to the felt which as you said muted and provided traction, but in turn provided a different set of reations.
I realize that there millions of tangents presented here; however, my first thought was frequency. As in vibrational reaction and responses. Starting with the initial contact each successive contact is altered by every physics law applied all at once and varied by each individual response and following reaction.
The acrylic material is a highly melodic type of material in other words, it conducts high moving frequencies and sound vibrations. Think of dropping an 8 foot long 2x4 on a concrete floor. The board will hit the floor, bounce, make a sound, and all the while it will be vibrating at differing frequencies throughout it's length from end to end. The length and width will obviously influence all of those responses and reactions accordingly, along with density and weight. Of course this is just one set of variables. Other variables like reflex, rebound, sound waves, and so on....
Hopefully you and your physics enthusiasts can see the amazing possibilities presented here.

The previous dominoes, ie the tail, move slower and slower for more motion happening at the front. It's like a pulley system in a way. With enough dominoes, the tail segment is laying down almost fully while the pieces which haven't yet fallen are starting to. You have an impact which sends a lot of that energy in to the isolated piece causing a spike in velocity. Then the front of the tail lays down on the previously impacted component. So you have the initial spike and acceleration but that piece slows down when the piece lays on it for the second time because it is being limited from falling all the way over.


As for the asking questions bit... ie: to simplify a problem, break it down and create stepping stones or building blocks... I do this in programming. In fact, it is why programming exists. You create something small to do a set task. You plug that in where you need that task done and you use it as a building block in your application. The problem I see most with developers is them going to great lengths to make a problem seem more complicated than it is and failing at completing the task because they end up writing algorithms lasting thousands of lines, unbroken, which could've been solved by many smaller algorithms.


I always tell my students to write out what they want to do - design... Then expand on that. What do you mean by this, how is this done? etc.. etc.. I also advise them to find repetition in code, and turn it into a helper. Something simple being shadowed text ( which is just drawing the shadow first, offset, then the other line of text second so it renders on top and turning it into a function so instead of writing 2 lines of code each time, they write 1 ) or drawing a rectangle with an L bracket on 2 corners or so ( Which is just DrawRect and DrawLine * 2 * 2 for 2 corners. I usually set up an Ex function to draw in all 4, then a normal non Ex with fewer args which calls the Ex for the most common corners - 1 line of code to make something visually appealing ).


Things that are more useful can be simplified the same way.. Huge benefits to this means you can build up a repo of building blocks you can pick and choose from, so if you design something in the simplest form, you can expand on it and see if any of your previous blocks exist.. More times than not, you will re-use a lot of code.


For structures, I use Accessor Functions ( dynamically generated functions ) for my getters / setters ( and even more which communicate with those such as Get Value then ToString combined into 1, Has Value via Get != None )... using these AccessorFuncs I can write 1 line and generate 50 functions. I can generate helpers for an object to reset data, set, or whatever in 1 line for systems that require setting / getting / resetting data to these more than 1 point at a time and if I want to put it on 1 line instead of multiple SetX( 0.0 ), SetY( 0.0 ), SetZ( 0.0 ) I can just do Reset( 'x', 'y', 'z' ).... Most of the functions I create are for the value, but the others, such as Reset helper for the object, may only be 1/3 the amount and only the first time per object... but it makes it so I can create a new 3D position object in 3 lines plus the setup of 3 lines. X / Y / Z exists, I can auto generate a tostring output to include these auto generated or write one manually if I want to include other information.


etc.. etc.. etc..


I don't understand why people would generate thousands of lines of code all of which stems on basic repetition... I would rather spend time creating something new, adding it to my library and move on. That's why I do what I do. Efficiency matters, as well as accuracy. If there is a mistake - you fix it in 1 place instead of 10s or thousands.


I see it over and over and I try to help correct that behavior, or to overcome the sense that a complex problem requires complex code, to allow them to create working applications much quicker than previously. Although, I do generate walls of text sometimes.

I've seen another curious phenomenon: When striking a hard surface, like a desktop, with a sharpened, wooden pencil at a steep angle, the graphite tip does not hit just one time. It skips. There are two sequential line segments. What is happening here? My guess is that the pencil tip bends more quickly than the rest of the pencil body. 17 months and 2 weeks later and here I am finally thinking about what is actually creating the conditions of the "steady" state velocity of the various systems... It looks like they almost alternate between high and low velocity about a steady state average, and from the video it appears as though they also alternate in how chaotic their individual motion is. A domino will approach another at a comfortable speed and more or less levering about it's bottom corner and strike it. That solid strike will propel the next domino with great aplomb. This domino will subsequently strike the next even harder! But instead of going even faster than the last, it loses speed due to all the bouncing around it does in response to its getting wholloped.


So this implies that there is a spacing that is optimal for producing a true steady state velocity, at which they would strike each other with the maximum possible energy that doesn't produce chaotic motion. I wonder if that spacing has any other interesting properties or relationships with the geometry and material nature of the dominoes themselves.

I think you missed an important analysis here, if you looked at this phenomenon with a stochastic eye. There seems to be a clear difference in the "variance" of the speed caused by felt vs hardwood. Just like you did a moving average, you could show a moving variance. From this data, felt seems to be less stable around the average, with a higher variance than hardwood (much more aggressive spikes and dips). It'd be interesting to know why. Maybe it's because hardwood lets dominoes slide and that smooths out their twist and resistance to hits. Also, from the data it seems that the variance with felt decreases over time. It'd be interesting to know whether this is just a chance, or whether this must be the case. With a longer experiment, would the felt graph get closer around the moving average, or would aggressive spikes happen again after some time?


Another interesting analysis you missed is about the "period" of the twists. It definitely seems from the footage that the twists have a period (like a wave) that perhaps can be predicted. They seem to have a twist in a certain direction, that goes from more aggressive to less aggressive over time; then at some point the twist becomes null and a new twist starts in the opposite direction. Even from the graph you can see the effects of this, as a change in the speed, which has the shape of a wave. So, maybe you could try to fit a cosine wave to the data to describe this pattern mathematically?

For recording the subsequent domino timings, you could've just used the waveforms in the audio to see when one domino hits the next, no need to be supper accurate with the moving contraption or use a high speed camera for the sole puplrpose of keeping time.

The difference between the felt and the wood floor is the coefficient of friction (and probably some deflection of the felt). With the friction between the dominos and the felt, the dominos' moments of rotation stay at the front bottom corners of the dominos. On the wood floor, the bottom of the domino slips, so the moment of rotation is higher than the bottom of the domino, and the center of mass doesn't move as far (or as fast).

That twist looks to be caused by the intermediate axis theorem (also called the tennis racket theorem). That is, for a domino shaped object, there are 3 possible axes of rotation, two stable and one which is inherently unstable. The unstable axis is the same axis which the dominos in a typical domino chain rotate about, causing this rotation. I wonder if you set up a domino chain with the dominos rotating about a stable axis (ex. You stack them up on their sides instead of standing up) if the dominos would indeed have a steady state velocity...

Dominoes don't turn in the center of the gravity. They turn around a fixed point that will be bellow it if the impact point is produced above (and viceversa).
Aproximately the vertical distance between the rotation point and the CoG is equal to -(L^2)/(12·d), being d the distance between the CoG and the impact and L the total height of the piece.

That twist-slam motion is an oscillation between rotational kinetic energy and translational kinetic energy! The given translational speed is missing a component to its equation. I think this problem could be best solved from an energy approach!

To quantify the aforementioned oscillation, an improved camera rig needs to be built! It needs a second camera that's orthogonal to the plane of the ground to capture the intial orientation of the dominos. It also needs third camera that's coplanar with the second but revolved around the focus axis presented by the first camera. The third and second camera can be used such that the transformation of a particular face of a domino can be established in three dimensions. This will give you the majority of the missing information. The last part is the energy dissipated by heat and sound, but that may fall within margin of error given the other components of the system.

Here's a good question for you, Destin. And with a little thought you already know the answer. Does the speed keep increasing? Since each falling domino adds energy to the system, one might expect that that energy gets transferred to the next domino constantly increasing the speed. If you've watched even a few videos of large domino displays, you already know the answer. The sound is constant. The falling dominos have a steady tone. The series of impacts, each with a little click sound, remains constant. Here's a paper describing some of the complex physics: https://arxiv.org/abs/1301.0615
Two basic concepts seem to dominate the explanation: 1) It takes some time for a domino to fall, and 2) There is some friction between the dominoes as they slide past each other.

Hi Dustin

You said your results didn't stack up to the theory, so I took the liberty of checking your math (1:03 ish) and it all made sense.(Assuming I've correctly understood 'w' is the 'width of the domino'? - it's not defined anywhere)

However I suggest your 'Position of CofG' definition of X should have used Sin(theta) not Cos(theta), for the following reason:

Your diagram defines your starting angle at 90 deg, not 0 deg, so in the limiting case of 'Domino A' being bolt upright, theta is 90 deg. In this position, due to width of the domino you'd expect a CofG offset of -'ve 'w/2' in the implied X vector direction.

So we're expecting magnitude 'w/2' from the math when 'theta=90 deg'.

Taking your equation:

X=(Gap/2) - ((w/2)*(Cos(theta)))

and looking at just the width CofG offset element (eg '((w/2)*(Cos(theta)))') and applying theta=90 deg gives

(w/2)*(cos(90deg))=w/2*(0)=0

However:
(w/2)*(sin(90deg)=w/2*(1)=w/2

If this is indeed a mathematical blunder it would throw your predictions out, but perhaps by an insignificant amount. Only the numbers will tell you, and I couldn't catch those.

If you really want to nail the experiment, I suggest an Uncertainty Budget may be worth pursuing to quantify all the sources of experimental error. You may decide you can't control the parameters well enough to 'experimentally prove' the theory, in which case you'd be in good company with most of the experimental Physicists of the world!

Yours Sincerely
Ian H

The wood one accelerates way slower because it doesn't have as much force to hit the next one. It uses it's center of gravity as it's pivot. Imagine a baseball bat.. Now hit a ball while holding the center of the bat. It didn't give as much power as if you were to hold the base. It also pivots with a smaller circle causing the edge to hit lower. It makes it harder to push the next one. This method can potentially have a very fast max speed. As it keeps accelerating for a long time. and the limit is higher. But the carpet version can accelerate much faster and has a consistent fall (speed and angle). Which makes it hard to slow down. The carpet works way better; more control and consistency in each fall.

Destin, there's an additional kinetic energy sink that seems to be affected by the surface the dominoes are on. The dominoes don't just impact and twist, there are multiple impacts, just like switch bounce. If you watch the dominoes 3-6 behind the advancing wave front, this chatter continues for quite some time, sometimes resulting in the dominoes completely separating and a visible gap opening. You didn't include as much ultra-slow footage of the felt, so I can't say for sure, but it appears the bounce is far less damped on wood. On felt, the chatter seems to subside only a few dominoes behind the wave front, but on wood, on the "slam" contacts, the shockwave can be seen propagating backwards through the collapsed stack and inducing even more bounce. I can't decide whether I think this contributes to felt winning the race by increasing the magnitude of the initial impact (dead blow hammer vs. ball-peen), or if it actually indicates that the felt is robbing energy from the collisions, which makes the race closer than it might otherwise be.

The process is chaotic and cannot be predicted. The friction of each domino with the floor and the imperfections in the contact surfaces will control the magnitude and direction of the twisting. The kinetic energy imparted at each collision will vary and, as you observed, the point of contact will impart a different rotational momentum to each domino in the chain, leading to a chaotic propagation velocity of the wave. I suggest you make a longer chain of hinged dominoes at least twice as long. The hinges will control twist and the surface friction will be invariant. (Assuming spherical frictionless hinges in a vacuum.)

Since the rotation happens around an axis that doesn't have the maximum or minimum moment of inertia, it is in and of itself unstable!

Try it yourself: take a book and toss it in the air making it spin around different axis.

You'll notice that the rotation doesn't get all wonky only if you make it spin like a frisbee with the axis perpendicular to the surface of the book (maximum moment of inertia) and when the axis is parallel to the rib of the book (minimum moment of inertia).

No matter how hard you try, you'll notice that making it spin around an axis like the one on the dominoes, leads to a drift in the initial motion you give to the book causing it to deviate in an unpredictable and unstable pattern.

You know what's a good parallel to this analysis of dominoes?

Lightning.

Lightning is essentially just large-scale static electrical discharges. And yet because of the scale of lightning, plus the fact that it's a legitimate hazard, we've studied the phenomenon down to the bone, and have special names for all of its unique minutiae. You can't say the same thing for static electricity.

So in a similar vein, if dominoes had always been a game of stacking football fields full of monoliths, we'd already know everything being revealed in this video.

That was pretty cool actually. It looked like even when dominoes are spaced the same distance apart, if they are too far apart, you could have some of them fall and then the whole thing stops. And the reason was because the only reason the first ones were falling was because the domino was getting pushed forward before it fell; so it got closer, but as energy was lost from the system, because of twisting for example, it stopped pushing the domino in front as far forward until it didn't get close enough to the one in front to even knock it over. Without observing with a camera like that, one might not be able to guess that that is what was happening and just remain confused over why some could fall over and not all. So, you might guess that you need to stack them closer and better aligned, but not really understand what bounderies there are and so it's all trial and error. And of course, that's no way to engineer something.

The graphs reminded me of the gears of a car. On the slippery surface the dominoes accelerate faster, because the bottom of the bricks slide from underneath it, making it easier to push the center of gravity over the tipping point and therefore needs less force. The carpet doesn't do that, which causes more required force to tip the brick over, therefore you need more initial force, but because the dominoes are closer together (no slipping backwards AFTER being hit) they have a higher top speed.

Less friction on the hardwood causes more profound 3D rotation around the centre of gravity.
The higher friction felt moves the centre of gravity down giving more leverage to result in a higer velocity and horizontal distance traveled of each domino's top end (while the bottom end also travels a smaller negative distance from it's zero point), which increases the period and amount of energy translated into the next domino.
Small variations in the moment of impact then causes a high difference in the friction experienced by each dominoe's bottom end (especially on felt, less so on the low friction hardwood) and this in turn causes variations in the "true" centre of gravity of each domino causing the chaotic oscillation in velocity observed throughout the series.. just a jab at it by a Biologist, don't kill me.

A couple things I noted. In aerodynamics the interaction between center of gravity and center of pressure is important. All of the research seems to focus on rotation around the base or the c.o.g. but it can't be as simple as this. Since drag is a form of friction, the friction on the ground could be considered drag, with thrust coming from the dominoes behind it. The amount of drag and the drag vector would change as the dominoes fall, changing its speed. It seems to me that research needs to be done on a single domino first to understand it falling and to determine these different force vectors.

Let me comment something I figure out in this fascinating video
First, in your video, the rotation and the falling motion are kind of a perturbation to transmit the energy down the domino series.
To me, it makes a lot of sense. As long as the dominoes pass through, the total potential energy should be transformed into kinetic energy of the last domino.(Of course also some lost of energy from heat or deformation)
We can see the falling domino bouncing over and over between the falling and fallen dominoes, so it's kind of transmitting two different energy, "rotating" and "falling" energy to only kinetic energy.
Also, there is a point why there is a perturbation. As the domino tend to rotate, more time is needed to catch up to the next domino. But the fun thing is that as you rotate more, you tend to bump into the previous rotating domino, the bumping makes the perturbation of the domino that changes the rotating energy transform to falling and kinetic energy. But the perturbation needs time, and the previous dominoes should also be considered, which makes a cycle of spikes.
Last, still no good answer for which is faster, the heartwood or the felt. To me I'll guess it would be the same average velocity for both two. So, I was thinking. It seems to me you overlooked one mayor factor - the initial velocity and rotation of the first domino (not to underestimate your cousins ability to push dominoes...). Because, if you think about it, the "rotation" you speak of probably comes from the rotation of the initial domino, and then propagates. In a perfect mathematical model, if you pushed the first domino straight, no rotation would occur - ever. Also, about the speed of propagation - it depends on the time it takes for one domino to clear the distance to the next one. Now, it can do so by falling straight down, in which case the time it takes is determined by gravity - so, quadratic. On the other hand, it can also rotate on the vertical axis hitting the next domino with one side, and this is linear. The true speed of propagation is then a combination of the two.

thats too much physics for me..

A domino that gets hit lower, and slides, should take longer to hit the next domino (lower propagation velocity), for two reasons. First, because the same energy is going into pushing a bigger effective mass (the whole domino rather than just part of it) forward, so you should get less velocity. Second, because gravity is putting energy into the system by toppling (once the domino reaches its tipping point, gravity accelerates its rotation, and the further it tips over, the more work gravity does on it, until it hits the ground), and a domino that gets hit lower will reach the tipping point later and topple slower.

re: 23andMe - I'm convinced that sending the only truly unique thing about yourself through the post to get analysed by a third party is an awful idea at the moment - it's too new of an industry to be regulated properly.

Sure, you can find out about your geneology, but you have no idea WHAT happens to that sample afterwards. All sorts of tests can be run on it, and all sorts of data can be developed and sold (your chance to develop incurable disease, maybe? insurance companies would LOVE to know that for example), and that's before you look at the security implications of DNA based encryption a few decades from now.
Your DNA is your most secret property. People need to understand that before giving third parties access to it. This sort of stuff is really trendy right now and it's being pushed hard by marketing. People need to think carefully before taking any irreversible action because this isn't like a lock you can change or a password you can alter if the data gets lost, stolen or sold. Think about how many companies you've heard of this year that have been hacked and had personal data stolen... if this happens to your genome it's a real issue.

The Dzhanibekov effect might play a role here... It might even be the principle mechanism responsible for the seemingly random twisting behaviour. This effect is also known as the "tennis racket theorem" which states that rotation of an object around its first and third principal axes is stable, while rotation around its second principal axis (or intermediate axis) is not - and looking at the slow motion footage it suddenly occurred to me that the dominoes are effectively rotating around their second principle axis as they fall down: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tennis_racket_theorem

The twist phenomenon is very interesting. I would be intrigued by replicating this with machined aluminum or steel dominoes. To me, it looks like the impact is able to bend the plastic slightly and induce this sort of oscillating propagation of that impact. It would be neat to see if metal dominoes 1) are simply more consistent (uniform wall, no sinkage) and 2) reduction in the vibration/flex changes the behavior. This was really neat to watch!

I started writing this comment at about 4:30 in the video where I paused to formulate some of my own hypotheses as to what's going on. So bear in mind that at this particular point in the comment, I have yet to watch the full length of the video. Be sure to read the whole thing through.

So one of the things that I observed in your attempts to suss out the physics of falling dominoes on paper is that you tried to reduce the problem down to the simplest possible case of just one domino simply leaning against the other. There's a problem with that. That's only taking into account one domino affecting the next. When in reality (and this is something that can be seen in the high speed camera footage), it's not just one domino leaning into the next to knock it over. It's that one domino and the several dominoes behind it that combine both their mass and momentum that overcomes the static resting momentum of the next domino in line to also knock it over. The energy wave propagates accordingly all the way through the line of dominoes.

You can't reduce the problem down to just one domino leaning against another and suss out the physics that way. You have to first reduce the problem down to one domino falling all on its own, figure out the momentum it gains through that perturbation of its stable resting state, and then re-expand the problem to a line of dominoes where the several dominoes behind the one at the end are already in the process of falling after having knocked each other over, and apply that to the domino at the end.

Now, back to watching the video~

Paused again at 10:15, these oscillations in the propagation velocity of the falling wave through the line of dominoes is definitely very cyclical and extremely fascinating to see in the slow motion! I can imagine that this would complicate the physics computation of it all.

I noticed another variable that makes the felt so chaotic - the dominoes don't sit vertically. This is more pronounced in the felt because it's uneven, but the smooth hardwood still has this problem because the dominoes aren't perfectly square. Sometimes the dominoes angle away from each other and sometimes towards, changing the angle it needs to rotate a lot. This causes lots of variation in starting rotation speed and angle travelled, resulting in large peaks and troughs in the felt's velocity graph.

I am surprised you didn't talk about friction, when friction plays a huge part here. The velocity variation between hardwood and felt mainly occurs due to the coefficiant of friction of both materials being different. The reason why the felt graph is more chaotic is because it's coefficiant of friction is more. So the energy in the system decreases faster which reduces your velocity. Whereas if you look at the hardwood graph, it's velocity variation  is fairly constant. Which is also why when blue Iris took the average, in the end hardwood was faster. Not because it "caught up" but because felts energy was reducing much faster than hardwood. Also  material of the Dominoes matters too. Change the material and your results will change.

You said it yourself.... It's Basic Research. So, my suggestion is to get back to the basics. The absolute basics.

I think that some of the variability in your system comes from the boundary condition between the base of each domino and the floor. That boundary condition, for each domino in the chain, is ever so slightly different. There's differences in the geometry of the base of the dominoes. There are frictional differences. There's surface texture differences (especially on the carpet surface). I think those differences start the twisting phenomenon that you are seeing.

You didn't show the paper physics model that you were working on, but I bet that you were assuming a fixed boundary condition at the base of the dominoes, and not the highly variable conditions that exist.

I would develop an experiment that eliminates the variability in the boundary condition between the base of the domino and the floor. That will best match your paper physics model. How to do that? Perhaps you could tape each domino to the floor. Develop a very precise technique to tape the dominoes to the hardwood floor, at very precise spacing. Then, knock them down and generate your timing graph. Plus, with the dominoes taped down, setting up the system for another run should be relatively easy.

I think you will learn a lot from this very basic experiment. (Remember, do Basic Research.) My guess is that doing your best to eliminate the variation in the boundary conditions between the floor and the bottom of the domino will smooth out your timing graph. Also, I'd develop a mechanism to push over the first domino in a consistent manner. It looked like the first domino was being pushed long after it hit the second domino. I didn't like that variability either.

Destin, I'm still curious as to why you didn't have a proper control, for starting the domino chain. A human can not replicate the same, precise pressure. Nothing against your cousin, she did a fantastic job and I'm glad she was willing to participate. I would suggest having a marked area on whatever test surface you are using, have a mechanical instrument to start the domino chain and perhaps a mechanical instrument to remove the Lego spacer that you use to set up the chain.
Since you would then have a specific starting area, and a specific length of a Lego template, I was thinking you could attach a wire to both ends.
Having some slack in the wire, connect a second wire in the middle of the wire connected to the template. Connect the other end of the second wire to a machine, that can retract the template without fear of pulling it out unevenly. You could weigh down the retraction machine with simple free weights, if you do not have the option to secure the machine to the floor.
I hope this helps and I hope you continue this pursuit of knowledge.

I am wondering if you tighten up a few controllable variables you may improve some of the predictability and get some tighter numbers.

1. You are initiating the dominoes with a flat sided ruler pushed by hand. This could easily cause variables in the initial rotation of the dominoes and could introduce a more pronounced wave in the pattern of "rotating" dominoes to the "slam" dominoes. Doing it by hand could also introduce a greater or lesser initial momentum that gets carried through the whole set. Maybe initiate the dominoes with something like a spring fired pin that strikes the initial domino it the same spot and at the same speed every time.

2. Surface variables - For the hard wood there are going to be many variations from board to board that could possible effect results from run to run. Differences in grip from board to board, wood grains, the small gaps between boards. Looking at your graphs you see a moment where the hard wood actually accelerates to a speed greater than the felt before correcting back down. might be from a slightly higher traction on 1 board before correcting back down on a more slippery board. Felt can have an entire set of its own differences that could effect the dominoes on the other side. I'm thinking something like a long piece of class would be a good surface to do the "slick surface test" and possibly a long strip of rubber mat would be good for the "High Traction" test.

3. For ultimate comparison, I remember they used to have domino sets where it was plastic rails that each had 10 or so dominoes affixed, I think they are called pivot track dominoes... you would place these tracks of dominoes end to end to make your full run. You would have a run where every domino was in the exact same order facing the exact same direction running on a "constant fricktion surface". A good run of these affixed to a board to ensure consistent spacing between tracks, fired with a pin to ensure exact starting velocity, should give a somewhat "variable-less" run and may show once and for all if you can or can't predict the fall speed of a particular run of dominoes.

In either case, I love domino videos and I love your videos so maybe I am just being picky so I can see you make more domino videos.

Read up on "Chaos Theory". This is clearly a chaotic system. As with most chaotic systems, for example the Logistic Map, parameters determine the chaotic-ness. When dominoes are spaces together it's like the logistic map at A=3.1 where bifurcation barely took place (right twist, left twist). When dominoes are too far apart (as with A>4) the value 'escapes' towards infinity. Where the logistic map has one variable, with dominoes there are at least three variables (y-twist, z-twist and push-slide) when the playing field (parameters) are fixed.

You can probably even model this in a simulator, and make a plot by varying two parameters, to get nice fractal patterns.

But one thing: you over complicated your camera setup. The "I see the front side of this piece but the back side of this piece" problem could be solved by switching to a longer lens: instead of that 50mm you seem to be using (it could also be an 85mm or a 35mm, I'm not sure), go to the longest lens you can find, place the camera far, far away, and you'll have an almost flat view, with no perspective issues (on the scale that you're worried about).

I would suggest an MTO-1000A, which is a vintage 1100mm f/10.5 with a hybrid refractive-reflective design. Huge and heavy, but sharp. If you want something more pedestrian, I think opteka has a not-so-great 1000mm mirror lens.

You'll save a lot of testing time, but you'll need A LOT of light (f/10.5!!).

Still, your moving contraption worked great: it helped you get long takes with lots of pieces, that my suggested setup wouldn't allow
